newsitem.title: USA: Sen Moynihan to reintroduce stadiums bill Jan 21.
newsitem.headline: Sen Moynihan to reintroduce stadiums bill Jan 21.

text.p: U.S. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, (D-NY), who shook the municipal bond market last year when he introduced a bill to bar use of tax-exempt bonds for professional sports stadiums, will reintroduce the measure on January 21, a Moynihan aide said on Monday.

Simultaneously, Moynihan will reoffer a bill that would eliminate a federal curb on bond issuance that the senator says denies tax-exempt financing to large, private research institutions, the aide said.
That curb sets a $150 million cap on the amount of tax-exempt bonds that nonhospital 501(c)(3) organizations can have outstanding, the aide said.
Moynihan is reintroducing both bills on January 21, the first day that Senate leaders say members can offer bills in the 105th Congress.
House members, however, have the go-ahead from their leaders to introduce what is expected to be an avalanche of bills beginning tomorrow, January 7.
The Moynihan aide said the stadiums bill would have an effective date of when the Senate Finance Committee votes on the measure.

Moynihan's original bill had a June 14, 1996 effective data. He agreed to delay the effective date when bond dealers and issuers said the deadline had a chilling effect on some some major stadium financings and the market for stadium bonds.
Moynihan's aide said his boss may include some exemptions in the new bill, such as for a stadium "where the dollars are too small to be a problem or worth the effort."
An example of such a "de minimis" rule might be for a $1 million minor league stadium, the aide said. He stressed that the $1 million figure is an arbitary one.
Another exemption could involve charitable sports events, the aide said.

"Say, some football teams play a game over at college campus where the proceeds go to the college (which is) a 501(c)(3)," he said. "Or maybe some sports team plays for the United Way," the aide said.
"That type of use involves the tax subsidy inuring to the benefit of a charity," the aide said.
